1.1.2 Introduction

This document does not offer a full explanation of our new TEI-based XML markup. It instead provides a brief summary of the steps required to perform specific actions in a way that relates our new practices to our old workflow. Although many TEI elements have intuitive and straightforward names, some of them mean different things than we would expect, so it’s important that editors read this document carefully.

We assume that readers are familiar with certain key XML concepts and the means of expressing them within documentation: principally element (and the distinction between empty and non-empty ones), attribute, attribute value and entity. Elements are what most people would likely call tags, such as p. Attributes are used to define the characteristics of the element to which they are attached. In the following example, <p rend="indent0">, ‘p’ (the element) has a ‘rend’ attribute (usually depicted as rend within documentation) with a value of ‘indent0’. Entities are the chief method used to encode certain special characters within a document. You will rarely need to use them within our letters since most characters should just be entered using the Character Map as you are currently doing. However, certain very special characters should be entered using our custom defined named entities, as described in our documentation below. It is essential that everyone is entirely clear about these terms, and understand the principle of nesting elements. These concepts are not difficult to grasp and are explained in any guide to XML. Newcomers to the language may find the Text Encoding Initiative’s ‘Gentle Introduction to XML’ useful.

1.1.3 Schema, namespace and document root

At the top of every file, there will be a few lines of text that you can basically ignore. They will be the same at the top of every file and relate to the schema and various custom entity definitions. Don’t worry about these lines; just make sure that you don’t make any changes to them. The first important line is the TEI element. This is the root element. It contains a mandatory xml:id attribute that provides the unique identifier for the document on the site. This should be composed of the text ‘DCP-LETT-’ followed by the calendar number for the document (e.g. ‘<TEI xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" xml:id="DCP-LETT-10038">’;. If the calendar number contains a letter, be sure that it is entered in uppercase Also do not add leading zeros to the calendar number. This xml:id value also serves as the base file name for the document, so be sure to that the xml:id value AND the document’s file name are kept in sync. On all the older records, TEI is preceded by an XML comment that gives the old file name for the item.


<!--OLD FILENAME:10038_7387.xml--><TEI xml:id="DCP-LETT-10038" xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> ⋯
</TEI>

1.1.4 Three main parts of each TEI file

Every TEI letter file will have three portions:

  1. teiHeader. This is the header of the TEI file, not of the letter text. It contains all the metadata about both the source document and the electronic file. In some ways, it will consist of both what we had in existing metadata in the old DarXML files — what used to be calendar data — but also of some of what would previously have gone in dot notes, such as revisions made to the electronic file by any of the editors.
  2. facsimile, which contains information about the images available for the document on CUDL. Editors can safely ignore this section since it will be maintained by Mike Hawkins.
  3. text, which contains everything that ends up being printed in the volume with a letter. It’s not simply the letter “text”. It also contains enclosures, CD notes, annotations, translations, and footnotes. Quite simply, it’s everything that makes up the letter and our editorial work on it, as opposed to the metadata that we have about it.

1.1.5 teiHeader

teiHeader contains three elements that must appear in the following order:

  • fileDesc
  • profileDesc
  • revisionDesc

1.1.5.1 fileDesc

fileDesc contains information about the electronic file and the physical letter’s source(s). Please note that THIS is where the provenance information now goes, not after the letter. It also contains a mix of volume information relevant to the print publication of the letter in the same place as other information about the digital publication of this letter.

1.1.5.1.1 Title or To/from line

The line that appears at the top of each letter stating the correspondent and the date is now the title and appears at the top of the teiHeader. Note that it is still possible to put footnote markers in here at any point required:

<titleStmt>
 <title xml:id="main_title">From William Marshall<ref target="#foot.f1"/>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; 2 June 1875</title>
</titleStmt>

If the document also contains a translation, then you will need to provide footnote pointers (ref) to the different header footnotes that will appear in the original and translated versions:

<titleStmt>
 <title xml:id="main_title">From William Marshall<choice>
   <seg type="original">
    <ref target="#foot.f1"/>
   </seg>
   <seg type="translation">
    <ref target="#foot_trans.f1"/>
   </seg>
  </choice>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; 2 June 1875</title>
</titleStmt>

This line will need to be edited whenever the correspondent and date are changed, though we are investigating ways of automating the construction of the title. The choice element groups the two seg (segments) that contain the pointers that are to be used in the original letter (<seg type="original">) and the translated version (<seg type="translation">).

1.1.5.1.2 Publication information

publicationStmt contains a lot of metadata that used to be in calendar data, as well as some that used to be in the letter itself. To reduce duplication, this is the only place, log number, and provenance are recorded, other than the file name and accordingly the xml:id for the letter.

1.1.5.1.2.1 To find or change the calendar and log numbers

To change the calendar number, modify the xml:id on the root TEI element, as described above. Remember that the xml:id takes the format ‘DCP-LETT-’ followed by the calendar number (with any letters appearing in uppercase): ‘DCP-LETT-1G’. Do not add leading zeros to the number.

The lognum is coded using idno with type value of “lognum”.

<idno type="lognum">1851</idno>
1.1.5.1.3 To find or change the volume number

Below publicationStmt you find seriesStmt (series statement). This contains information about the correspondence volume(s) in which the letter was published.

<seriesStmt> &amp;titleSeries;
&amp;DC-Vol3;
</seriesStmt>

Simply change the volume number in the entity name. Put it in the form &DC-Vol3; for example for volume three. If a letter occurs both within a volume and a supplement, add entity references for both:

<seriesStmt> &amp;titleSeries;
&amp;DC-Vol3;
&amp;DC-Vol7-Supplement;
</seriesStmt>

A full list of the available volumes can be found in our Entity List. Most of the volumes should already be defined. However, if you find yourself needing to enter a volume/supplement that hasn’t been defined, contact Liz Smith or Mike Hawkins and they'll create a new entity for you.

1.1.5.1.4 To record an alternate source for a letter

For situations where we want to record an alternate version of a letter, but we aren’t using it for the transcription we are publishing (i.e. we are publishing a draft version, but we want to record that there is also a copy of the same letter in the archive), use notesStmt. It immediately follows seriesStmt. It can contain one or more relatedItems with a type containing ‘copy’, ‘draft’, ‘publication’ or ‘translation’. If type is equal to anything other than ‘publication’ and it seems useful to record where the alternative manuscript version is, it is possible to add an optional subtype that contains a brief abbreviation for the item’s holding institution (e.g. ‘CUL’, ‘NHM’ or ‘Liverpool’. These relatedItem elements each contain a bibl that describes items related to the current document, e.g.:

<relatedItem type="publication">
 <bibl>
  <hi rend="italic">Correspondence</hi> 1: 1</bibl>
</relatedItem>

or

<relatedItem type="copy" subtype="CUL">
 <bibl>CUL DAR 152: 659a</bibl>
</relatedItem>

or

<relatedItem type="draft" subtype="CUL">
 <bibl>CUL DAR 201: 24v</bibl>
</relatedItem>
1.1.5.1.5 To find or change the physical description

The old calendar data and description elements are now coded as <note type="physdesc"> (calendar data) and <note type="description"> (how the description will appear at the bottom of the letter). These elements are placed within notesStmt with relatedItem. The elements in notesStmt can go in any order. Please remember that these used to be in msDesc but should not be put there anymore. In the past there was sometimes an n value inside <note type="physdesc"> but this no longer needs to be maintained.

<notesStmt>
 <note type="physdesc">AdraftS 1p</note>
 <note type="description">ADraftS</note>
</notesStmt>

At least for now, both the physdesc and description need to be maintained. If you're trying to change a description, you should make sure that the note with the attribute <note type="description"> contains the text that you want to appear at the end of the volume. The physdesc note should still be correct, but may well also contain extra information from the calendar. There should be no more than one of each of these types of notes.

1.1.5.1.6 Postmarks and datestamps

If an item contains a postmark (or a datestamp in the case of a telegram), it should go in notesStmt with the description and provenance, and related items (if there are any). It doesn’t matter what order you put them. Postmarks and datestamps are simply notes with types postmark or datestamp respectively:

<notesStmt>
 <note type="postmark">JA 17 1825</note>
 <note type="physdesc">AdraftS 1p</note>
 <note type="description">ADraftS</note>
</notesStmt>
1.1.5.1.7 Endorsement

If a letter has an endorsement, it goes in notesStmt like postmarks and datestamps (see above).

<notesStmt>
 <note type="postmark">JA 17 1825</note>
 <note type="endorsement" subtype="letter">‘/76’</note>
 <note type="physdesc">AdraftS 1p</note>
 <note type="description">ADraftS</note>
</notesStmt>
1.1.5.1.8 The description of the source (<sourceDesc>)
1.1.5.1.8.1 To find or change the provenance

Again, this will NOT be included below the letter anymore in the xml letter file. The provenance will only be found in sourceDesc in the teiHeader. That said, please remember that currently the text in <bibl type="provenance"> will appear both under the letter in the printed volume and online; don’t put any information in this field that cannot appear online. There is still some duplication as we will for the time being use both bibl to record the provenance in its printed form and we will also have a more granular version of the provenance below. Manuscript sources should be described using msDesc as below. For printed sources, use <bibl type="printSource"> (which is coded much like the main provenance, so make sure you have the type right!).

Manuscripts take the following form:

<bibl type="provenance">DAR 144: 119</bibl>
<msDesc>
 <msIdentifier>
  <repository key="../repo/repo_106.xml">CUL</repository>
  <collection>DAR</collection>
  <idno>144: 119</idno>
 </msIdentifier>
</msDesc>

If a particular letter is derived from more than one manuscript document, add a separate msDesc for each one.

For printed sources, simply put the text that makes up the reference in a <bibl type="printedSource"> following the <bibl type="provenance">:

<sourceDesc>
 <bibl type="provenance">
  <hi rend="italic">LL</hi> 3: 219</bibl>
 <bibl type="printedSource">
  <hi rend="italic">LL</hi> 3: 219</bibl>
</sourceDesc>

If a particular letter is derived from more than one printed document, add a separate <bibl type="printedSource"> for each one.

If a letter is drawn from a combination of manuscript and printed sources, each individual source should be coded using the appropriate ‘tag’ as described above (i.e. msDesc, if it's a manuscript and <bibl type="printedSource">, if it's print). Try to list the sources in the same order in which they appear in the provenance and make sure that everything is inside sourceDesc:

<sourceDesc>
 <bibl type="provenance">DAR 153: 98; Lawrences Auctioneers, Crewkerne, Somerset (dealers) (2009); <hi rend="italic">LL</hi> 3: 219<ref target="#foot.f14"/>
 </bibl>
 <msDesc>
  <msIdentifier>
   <repository key="../repo/repo_106.xml">CUL</repository>
   <collection>DAR</collection>
   <idno>153: 98</idno>
  </msIdentifier>
 </msDesc>
 <bibl type="printedSource">Lawrences Auctioneers, Crewkerne, Somerset (dealers) (2009)</bibl>
 <bibl type="printedSource">
  <hi rend="italic">LL</hi> 3: 219</bibl>
</sourceDesc>

1.1.5.2 profileDesc

profileDesc describes the correspondents, the summary of the letter and any associated categories.

1.1.5.2.1 To change the correspondent

The correspondent is now located in a section called correspDesc, which is new to TEI. It works by listing correspondence actions, such as sending and receiving, which is how we distinguish between sender and recipient.

<correspAction type="sent">
<!-- This is the sender -->
 <persName key="../nameregs/nameregs_1.xml">Darwin, C. R.</persName>
 <placeName>Abinger Hall Down letterhead</placeName>
 <date when="1875-06-14">14 June [1875]</date>
</correspAction>
<correspAction type="received">
<!-- This is the recipient -->
 <persName key="../nameregs/nameregs_4239.xml">Schultze, Fritz</persName>
</correspAction>

So the sender is listed first, and this is also where the date goes. Within each correspAction there is an active person, and that person is named in a persName (if the sender is a person) or orgName (if the sender is an organisation). If the correspondent is the representative of an organisation, it's permitted to put first the individual in a persName, and then to follow it with the organisation in an orgName, as long as there is an already existing name register entry for the organisation (if you want to record the organisation and there isn't an entry already, one should be created). In both cases, persName or orgName include a link to the name register file in key, as in the above example, rather than just listing the id number. The key attribute is mandatory — each correspondent MUST point to an nreg file. If one does not yet exist, create one. If the letter was sent or received by more than one individual, each one would have their own persName included within the appropriate correspAction. persName is used for a single individual, such as Asa Gray. It may also be used to refer to a group of individuals, like the Fellows of the Linnean Society. orgName, in contrast, is used for organisations, such as The Linnean Society itself. You can automatically open the namereg file if you hold down CTRL (Windows) or CMD (Macintosh) and click on its filename. If the individual in question is a new correspondent, don’t forget to create the namereg file immediately and to point to it with key. For example, to pointto the namereg file for Fritz Schultze, you’d give key and value of ‘../nameregs/nameregs_4239.xml’.

Remember that some of the correspodent details are repeated in the title, so be sure that you make any relevant changes there as well.

1.1.5.2.1.1 Alternative correspondents

If the correspondent is either one person or another, then you should enter both correspondents with an xml:id and exclude. For example, if the recipient of the letter is either W. W. Baxter or William Baxter, the receiving correspAction should be thus:

<correspAction type="received"
 subtype="personGrp">
<!-- This is the recipient -->
 <persName xml:id="name1" exclude="#name2"
  key="../nameregs/nameregs_332.xml">Baxter, W. W.</persName>
 <persName xml:id="name2" exclude="#name1"
  key="../nameregs/nameregs_333.xml">Baxter, William</persName>
</correspAction>

When you are needing to deal with mutually exclusive options, you first go through and supply a unique xml:id to each of the elements to be excluded (in this case persName). The xml:id values only need to be unique within the document, so I'd recommend using something like <xml:id="name1"> on the first name, <xml:id="name2"> on the second, etc. If there are more than two possibilities, you can list more than one element in the exclude list.

1.1.5.2.1.2 Dates

To change the date, currently it must be changed in two places: the title element and the date in <correspAction type="sent">. If changing the date of a letter means that it will be published in a different volume than the one it was originally assigned to, remember to change the volume information in <SeriesStmt>.

The date will most often be contained in date in the <correspAction type="sent">. In some cases we may know when the letter was received, but as we haven’t been recording this we will leave that out for now. For a letter with a known date, even if conjectured, use <date when="">. If there is a range, you should use <date notBefore=""> and <date notAfter"">. You should combine notBefore and notAfter in the same date element. For situations where we only know one terminus (i.e. [before 16 Feb 1879]) put the known date into the appropriate attribute. You would then put one of two canonical values into the other attribute (see below). So for a [before] date, put <notBefore=1809-01-01> and <notAfter=1879-02-15>. For a date where we know it must be after something, i.e. [after 16 Feb 1879], use the known terminus: <notBefore="1879-02-17> and for the other use <notAfter="1882-12-31">.

Dates should be encoded using date and they contain two major parts:

  1. the textual content of the element containing a natural language version of the date (e.g. “1 Jan 1880;” “after 1 Jan 1880”; “22 June 1874–82”)
  2. one (or possibly two) attributes (when, notBefore and notAfter) containing ISO date values (yyyy-mm-dd) entered into one or more of the possible three attributes; these are when, notBefore and notAfter and are used for sorting and searching the letters.
1) The textual contents of date should contain a natural language version of the date, entered largely as before (e.g. 1 Jan 1880; after 1 Jan 1880; before 1 Jan 1880; 1-10 Jan 1880; Oct–Dec 1846, 22 June [1874?],
[c. 31 Jan 1878?]
. Please put months in using these abbreviations: Jan Feb Mar Apr May June July Aug Sept Oct Nov Dec. Do not italicise "c." or it will not come up in the search results.

2) An ISO version of the date (‘yyyy-mm-dd’) is additionally stored within one (or more) of three possible attributes:

  • when, which is used when the letter is known (or can be inferred) to have been written on a precise day
  • notBefore, which is used to record the earliest date the letter could have been written - should be combined with <notAfter="1882-12-31">
  • notAfter, which records the latest date the letter could have been written - should be combined with <notBefore=1809-01-01>
a) When a letter is known (or can be inferred) to have been written on a precise date, this value should be recorded within when. This is the most commonly used dating attribute since the majority of dates of the letters are relatively straightforward. That is, we know (or have inferred) that it was sent on a specific date (e.g. 6 January 1880). In this case, you would enter the ISO value for the date in when (e.g.
<date when="1880-01-06">6 Jan 1880</date>
).

If a letter was known to have been written on more than one date (e.g. 1 January 1880 and then a later part added on 9 January 1880), you would create two date elements:

<date when="1880-01-06">1 Jan 1880</date>
<date when="1880-01-09">9 January 1880</date>

NB: Using multiple <date when="yyyy-mm-dd" /> elements with when does not define a range of dates (e.g. 1-9 January 1880). Rather, it defines multiple specific dates that the letter was known to have been written (e.g. 1 and 9 January 1880). To record date ranges, use notBefore and/or notAfter as described below.

b) Sometimes we know only that a date was written within a certain period of time (say 2–6 January 1880), or after a certain date (after 2 January 1880) or before a certain date (before 4 January 1880). In these cases you would use notBefore or notAfter, either appearing on their own or together in conjunction.

When a value is entered in notAfter, what you are saying is that the letter could not be written after that date. In other words, it was written on or before the value in notAfter :
<date notAfter="1880-01-05">[before 6 Jan 1880]</date>

(i.e. the letter was written on 5 January or earlier).

When a value is entered in notBefore, you are saying that the letter could not have been written earlier than the date in notBefore. That is, the letter was written on or after that date:
<date notBefore="1880-01-06">[after 5 Jan 1880]</date>

(i.e. it was written on 6 January 1880 or later).

When notBefore and notAfter are used together, they define a range of dates (inclusive of the values at both extremes) in which the letter could be written:
<date notBefore="1879-12-24"
 notAfter="1880-01-05">[24 Dec 1879 - 5 Jan 1880]</date>
.

NB: It is vital that careful attention is paid when entering values into notBefore and/or notAfter since they will often differ from the natural language date by +/- one day. The key to entering the correct value is to focus on the meaning of the attribute and what you are trying to communicate about the natural language version of the date. Don’t just plunk an ISO version of the natural language date into notBefore or notAfter.

For more complex dates, please see Appendix I: Dates at the bottom of this document.

1.1.5.2.2 Summary

The summary can be found after correspDesc and is now called abstract.

<abstract>
 <p>Thanks FS for his book [<hi rend="italic">Kant und Darwin</hi>].</p>
 <p>Sends regards to Haeckel.</p>
</abstract>

Keywords and search terms can be found immediately below it. For the time being, do not concern yourself with the keywords since the project needs to decide what it wants to do with them.

<textClass>
 <keywords>
  <term type="it" ref="#">Kant und Darwin</term>
  <term type="people" ref="#subject_2048">Haeckel, E. P. A.</term>
  <term type="rx" ref="#">Schultze, Fritz 1875</term>
  <term type="scientific_terms" ref="#">theory (including philosophy)</term>
  <term type="scientific_terms" ref="#">transmutation</term>
  <term type="social" ref="#">Darwin himself, domestic life</term>
 </keywords>
</textClass>

1.1.5.3 revisionDesc

There is a new section called revisionDesc that contains any actions performed on a file, including editing, proofreading, cancelling it and releasing any portion of it for publication online. Each action should be listed as a change with a when attribute giving the date of the change, and optional type and status attributes. The person who made it goes within a name element with an xml:id value that will be assigned by the senior editors when someone starts work, but is normally based on that person’s initials plus her or his surname, e.g. ‘acorrigan’, ‘sevans’, ‘mjhawkins’ or ‘esmith’ for Andy Corrigan, Michael Hawkins, Samantha Evans, or Elizabeth Smith (respectively).

New change elements should be added to the end of the list. If the xml:id value of any of the people working on the document has previously been declared, subsequent occurrences of her or his name take a sameAs value of # followed by the relevant string.

change has optional status attribute that takes the values ‘released’ or ‘cancelled’ as well as a type attribute, which must be one of the following: ‘letter’, ‘footnotes’ or ‘translation’).

type should only be included if status has a value of ‘released’. Their combination allows editors to indicate whether a particular part of the transcription has been cleared for online release.

The series of editorial actions is listed below. Please note that within each change element you should also type out what action has occurred in natural language. Also, there is a short-cut for the date. Simply type ‘ymd’ and type ctrl+space to get that day’s date in the form appropriate for a when attribute.

A newly transcribed file would have:

<revisionDesc>
 <change when="2015-10-02"
  status="transcribed" xml:id="rclarkson">Transcribed by Rosemary Clarkson</change>
</revisionDesc>

After the first and second proofreading, immediately after transcription, then add:

<change when="2015-11-02"
 status="initialProofCompleted" xml:id="esmith">Initial proofread completed by Elizabeth Smith.</change>
<change when="2015-12-02"
 status="secondProofCompleted" xml:id="apearn">Second proofreading completed by Alison Pearn.</change>

Footnoting, review, and editor response will similarly each be marked by a change element. In each case the change should be marked at the point at which the active editor considers the action to be finished because it will trigger a move into a separate folder.

<change when="2016-01-02"
 status="footnoted" xml:id="sinnes">Footnoted by Shelley Innes.</change>
<change when="2016-02-02" status="reviewed"
 xml:id="asecord">Reviewed by Anne Secord.</change>
<change when="2016-03-02"
 status="editorResponseCompleted">Editor response completed by <name sameAs="#sinnes">Shelley Innes</name>
</change>

Because copyediting and proofreading are both done on paper galleys, the change element should be put in when the corrections are entered. Both the person who did the action (copyediting or proofreading) and the person who enter the correction should be indicated:

<change when="2016-04-02"
 status="finalProofreadCompleted">Proofread by Elizabeth Smith. Corrections entered by Paul White.</change>
<change when="2016-05-02"
 status="copyedited">Copyedited by Samantha Evans. Corrections entered by Francis Neary.</change>

Editing the supplement requires a different set of change elements, so if you are working on a letter for the volume 30 supplement please use one of the reserved set of supplement status values. Some supplement letters will have been published before, or may have been worked on to a certain level before the letter was moved to the supplement. Accordingly, from footnoting through to copyediting, the following values should be used in the same way as the original equivalents:

  • sup-footnoted
  • sup-reviewed
  • sup-editorResponseCompleted
  • sup-finalProofreadCompleted
  • sup-copyedited

These values will appear as folders in the Oxygen project, just as footnoted, reviewed etc. do.

1.1.5.3.1 Put a letter online

To indicate that a letter had been cleared for online release, for example, the editor would use:

<change when="2016-03-10" type="letter"
 status="released">Letter cleared for online release by <name xml:id="sevans">Sam Evans</name>.</change>

The publication status for each part of the document must be specified in a separate change element. To indicate that the letter, translation, and footnotes had all been cleared for online release, the editor would need to use three separate change elements:

<revisionDesc>
 <change when="2016-03-09" type="letter"
  status="released">Letter cleared for online release by <name xml:id="esmith">Elizabeth Smith</name>.</change>
 <change when="2016-03-09"
  type="translation" status="released">Translation cleared for online release by <name sameAs="#esmith">Elizabeth Smith</name>.</change>
 <change when="2016-03-09" type="footnotes"
  status="released">Footnotes cleared for online release by <name sameAs="#esmith">Elizabeth Smith</name>.</change>
</revisionDesc>

Please note that after the first time you are putting in a change element, you cannot re-define your xml:id. The second time and subsequently, instead use sameAs with a hash symbol at the front of your id, as in the examples above.

1.1.5.3.2 To replace a letter text with a new one

When we find a new version of a letter that has already been published, such as if we find the actual letter that was sent where previously we had only a copy or a draft, several steps are required. If the text is similar enough that no corrections or minor corrections to the text are necessary and the letter doesn’t need to be re-edited, simply make the corrections to the text, change the provenance, and if useful record the previous version as a relatedItem. If the new text is substantially different and requires re-editing, or if there is calendar information (such as physical description) you want to keep, follow all the instructions below.

If there is any portion of the previous file that should be kept, i.e. if it’s a draft with manuscript alterations that we would like to preserve, or if there is existing calendar description information about the extent of the letter, copy the whole file into a folder in dcp-tei called “drafts” or the one called “copies” as relevant. If possible these will be connected to the letter texts and deposited in the Digital Library when the project wraps up.

Next, go to revisionDesc and add a change element with an status value of ‘offlineForRe-edit’ to indicate that the letter should be taken offline for re-editing:

<change when="2019-05-21"
 status="offlineForRe-edit">Marked for re-edit by <name xml:id="elsmith">Liz</name>
</change>

This will take the letter text and footnotes offline and replace them with a stock phrase on the website to the effect that the letter is being re-edited. It is possible to put the letter back online at any point by adding a further change with an status value of ‘re-released’. If you've already done something to this letter and already have an xml:id in this file, don’t forget to use sameAs with a hash symbol in front of your id for the name element. Assuming that any letter already published is being re-edited for the supplement, make sure to mark the letter for inclusion in the supplement to volume 30 in seriesStmt:

<seriesStmt> &amp;DC-Vol3;
&amp;DC-Vol30-Supplement;
</seriesStmt>

Next make sure the provenance is correct. If what already existed was just a stock description from an auction catalogue, it probably suffices to put a comment in somewhere that indicates that we once had that as a provenance. If the text we already had was from another version of the letter, for example a publication, draft, or copy, make the source information into a relatedItem in <noteStmt>, following the relatedItem instructions above. Edit the provenance so that it reflects the new source of the transcription.

At this point, go ahead and edit the transcription and replace the old text with the text for the new version of the letter. The footnote editing can wait until the editors working on the supplement get to it.

1.1.5.3.3 To cancel an entry
To cancel a letter, add a change in revisionDesc like this:
<change when="2016-03-10"
 status="cancelled">draft of DCP-LETT-1967.</change>
It's very helpful if you say why you cancelled the letter. This text will appear online with the label ‘Cancelled:’ added automatically in front of it. Please just use whatever wording you would like to have appear online, similar to what you would say in the letter list of a volume. There’s no need to add a name element. If you’re mentioning a specific letter by number, please precede it with ‘DCP-LETT-’ as in the example above - this will allow linking to be put in more easily in the future. Remove ALL volume information - just take out the whole of
<seriesStmt> &amp;titleSeries;
&amp;DC-Vol13;
</seriesStmt>
.

1.1.6 Facsimile

Don’t worry about this section for now. It will be used to keep information about images on CUDL.

1.1.7 Editing the letter

All the textual content of the letter as well as any enclosures, CD Notes and annotations, translations and footnotes is contained within the body element inside text. body is divided into three main sections: one for the letter, another for the translation and a final one for the footnotes. Each is coded as a separate div with type value of ‘letter’, ‘translation’ and ‘footnotes’

<text>     <body>         <div type="letter">             
<!-- Letter content goes here -->         </div>                              <div type="translation">             
<!-- Translation content goes here, if a translation is present. Otherwise omit this div. -->         </div>                              <div type="footnotes">             
<!-- Footnotes go here, if the document contains footnotes. Otherwise, omit this div. -->         </div>     </body> </text>

While <div type="letter"> is mandatory, the other two (<div type="translation"> and <div type="footnotes">) should only be created if they are actually necessary. If a document doesn’t contain a translation, for example, it shouldn’t have a <div type="translation">.

1.1.8 Opener

The address (placeName), date (date), salutation (salute), and salutation note (<seg type="supplemental">. Footnote markers can be put anywhere in the text.

<opener>
 <placeName>
  <hi rend="print">Down, | Beckenham, Kent. | Railway Station | Orpington. S.E.R.</hi>
 </placeName>
 <date>Sunday</date>
 <seg type="supplemental">(Home tomorrow)</seg>
 <salute>Dear Dyer.</salute>
</opener>

In certain rare instances, it is not possible to use opener without causing a validation error. This should only happen when encoding enclosed letters that also have a footnote describing the enclosure. If oXygen should complain that the opener is not allowed in the current context, use <ab type="opener"> instead of opener and <seg type="salute"> insteade of salute.

<ab type="opener">
 <placeName>
  <hi rend="print">Down, | Beckenham, Kent. | Railway Station | Orpington. S.E.R.</hi>
 </placeName>
 <date>Sunday</date>
 <seg type="supplemental">(Home tomorrow)</seg>
 <seg type="salute">Dear Dyer.</seg>
</ab>

1.1.8.1 Address

Address is now placeName. Please note that to indicate a printed letterhead, rather than marking it as italic we can specify that it is printed by using <hi rend="print">. As before, it should be represented exactly as it is on the letter.

1.1.8.2 Date

The date element in opener is used to record the date as it appears in the original manuscript or printed source. No dating attributes are necessary on this particular item. As with the address, indicate any printed portion of the date with <hi rend="print">. Superscripts should be represented with <hi rend="superscript">.

1.1.8.3 Salutation note/Sendname

After all the confusion of “SN” we have decided to call writing that is part of the header <seg type="supplemental">.

<seg type="supplemental">M<hi rend="superscript">r</hi>. Charles Darwin in Down, Beckenham, Kent, England.</seg>

It will appear left justified above the salutation as usual when it appears in print.

1.1.8.4 Salutation

This is exactly the same, just make the salutation salute

<salute>Dear Sir,</salute>

1.1.9 Letter body text

Prose paragraphs should be tagged with p. There is normally no need to record minor variations in the block formatting of paragraphs in the original source. Block formatting is typically only needed to indicate things such as centering, right justification, unusual first-line indention, hanging indents or ‘blockquote’ formatting. These formats are to be specified using rend.

If text is centered because it seems to be a section header, it should be tagged accordingly. Instead of using <p rend="centre"> use <ab rend="centre" type="head">.

TODO rend values on block structures (left, indents,etc)

1.1.10 Footnote markers

Footnote markers should take this form:

<ref target="#foot.f2"/>

“#foot.f2” will match a note at the bottom of the document with the xml:id value of “foot.f2”.

If the document also contains a translation, then you will need to provide two different pointers for the first footnote in the title, which refer users from the original document to the translation and vice versa:

<choice>
 <seg type="original">
  <ref target="#foot.f1"/>
 </seg>
 <seg type="translation">
  <ref target="#foot_trans.f1"/>
 </seg>
</choice>

<seg type="original"> contains the pointer that appears when viewing the original version; <seg type="translation"> contains the pointer that appears within the translation. If, for example, a footnote marker was needed after the name of the sender in a file containing a letter in both its original language and in the translation, it would be encoded as:

<title xml:id="main_title">From William Marshall<choice>
  <seg type="original">
   <ref target="#foot.f1"/>
  </seg>
  <seg type="translation">
   <ref target="#foot_trans.f1"/>
  </seg>
 </choice>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; 2 June 1875</title>

The last child div in body is <div type="footnotes">. It contain footnotes, each of which appear as note:

<note xml:id="foot.f1">For a translation of this letter, see Appendix I.</note>
<note xml:id="foot_trans.f1">For a transcription of this letter in its original German, see pp. 213–14.</note>
<note xml:id="foot.f2">See letter to William Marshall, 29 May 1875. CD had sent Marshall an ostrich feather that he had received from Thomas François Burgers.</note>

You do not need to provide duplicate note elements for footnotes whose contents are the same in both the original letter and the translation. You only need to create a new note element for the translation when no existing note has the content that you want (as is the case with the ‘foot.f1’, ‘foot_trans.f1’ example above).

The most important thing is that you ensure that you point to the desired footnote using <ref> (e.g <ref target="#foot.f12"/>) in the relevant place in the letter and translation. It’s also important to stress that you no longer need to worry about how the notes will be numbered in the final output versions of the letter/translation. Their numbering will be automatically (and correctly) created when the document is displayed. All that matters is that you point to the right note from the right place in the letter/translation. It doesn’t matter if <ref target="#foot.f12"/> is footnote 12 in the letter but only footnote 3 in the translation. Mike Hawkins’s XSLT code knows how they are to be numbered and will do so properly. Just be sure to point to the footnote containing the contents you want and all will be fine.

Footnote markers can also be placed on certain bits of metadata within the header, such as the <note type="description">, <note type="postmark">, <note type="endorsement"> and <bibl type="provenance">.

If you wish to place footnote markers on section titles, such as CD Notes, Annotations or Enclosure, create an anonymous block (ab) immediately inside the relevant div (i.e. <div type="cdnotes">, <div type="annotations">, <div type="enclosures">) and place a ref element coded as per the instructions above.

<div type="cdnotes">
 <ab>
  <ref target="#foot.f7"/>
 </ab>
 <note>…</note>
…

</div>

1.1.11 Letter cross references

Letter cross references in footnotes should now be tagged so that they will link directly to the letter referred to. Do this with a ref tag around the words describing the letter you’re referring to (i.e. ‘letter from E. A. Darwin, 5 [March 1823]’). You will need to give the ref an attribute of target, with ‘./’ immediately followed by the full file name of the letter referred to. This is what the sentence would look like:

See also the <ref target="./DCP-LETT-5.xml">letter from E. A. Darwin, 5 [March 1823]</ref>.

You will see some ref elements that are like this: <ref target="./DCP-LETT-5.xml" resp="#mjhawkins">. The resp is only there to indicate that these ones have been automatically generated. Do not add resp if you are manually coding a cross reference. resp is there to help us differentiate between the references that were generated automatically (and therefore could be incorrect) and those that editors have hand-coded themselves (which lack resp). Also, if you should happen to be editing a file with an automatically generated link such as this and you confirm its accuracy or correct it if it was inaccurate, please remove remove the resp.

Please note that that the value of target in the above examples is assuming that you are linking from one letter to another (or one namereg to another namereg, etc). If you are linking from one type of document (say a letter) to a different type of document (say a namereg), you need to put in the full relative path to the item. For example, if you want to put in a link in a letter to namereg_1, you would code it this way: ‘
... <ref target="../nameregs/nameregs_1.xml">Charles Darwin</ref> ...
.’

1.1.12 Lists

In the past we haven’t had a specific way to mark lists beyond indicating the layout for the print page, but now they should be enclosed in <list rend="ordered"> with each item on the list tagged item. If a list is numbered the number and joinging punctuation/separator should be transcribed exactly as it appears in the MS and tagged <label>.

<list rend="ordered">
 <item>
  <label>1.</label> “intense cobalt Blue”</item>
 <item>
  <label>2</label> “silver yellow”</item>
 <item>
  <label>4)</label> “deep copper red”.</item>
</list>

1.1.13 Intentionally blank whitespace in the original document

Instead of putting line breaks or strings of non-breaking spaces to represent intentionally created whitespace in the letter, use <space>. The dim (dimension) value (‘horizontal’ or ‘vertical’) states exactly what it says it does; the extent value is a numerical character indicating the extent of the space, and the unit value states what sort of units it is being measured in (normally ‘chars’, for characters, for horizontal whitespace, or ‘lines’ for vertical whitespace).

Many of the ways we used to use whitespace will be replaced with other, more meaningful elements. For example, a gap in the text, whether because it was left deliberately or because the manuscript has been damaged, should be tagged <gap>. See below.

1.1.14 Special characters

Most of the special characters that we encounter within the letters are unproblematic, such as those used in Western European languages. These should be entered using the Character Map as before. However, some characters, such as the less than or greater than signs (<, >), &, the male/female symbols, the angled braces (〈, 〉) and the characters for degrees, minutes and seconds, should be entered using named entities outlined elsewhere. oXygen knows all our defined entities and its autocomplete feature will suggest the full name to you as you are typing. For example, as soon as you enter &ma it will suggest all the entities whose names begin with ‘ma’. Just select &maleSymbol; from the list and it will be entered for you. A full list of the available volumes can be found in our Entity List.

1.1.15 Mathematics, fractions and equations

Fractions and equations should be marked up in MathML, and examples can be found in the full guidelines linked to from the intro to these short guidelines. If you have a simple fraction, here as an example is the appropriate markup for one half:

<formula>
 <m:math>
  <m:mfrac>
   <m:mn>1</m:mn>
   <m:mn>2</m:mn>
  </m:mfrac>
 </m:math>
</formula>

For anything more complicated, you can look at the longer Darwin xml guidelines or ask Liz for help.

1.1.16 Character formatting

Text that has been distinctively rendered in some way, e.g. underlined, italicised, superscripted, Small Capitals, etc., should be tagged using hi with a rend value, such as ‘underline’, ‘italic’, ‘superscript’ and ‘smallCaps’. For a full list of values, see the entry on hi in the Element Set documentation. It is possible to apply more than one token in the same rend. For example, if something was both superscripted and italic, it could be coded as:
<hi rend="superscript italic">superscripted italic text</hi>
Character formatting is also inherited, so if you had some superscripted text with only a portion of it coded in italics, it would be coded as:
<hi rend="superscript">superscripted <hi rend="italic">italic</hi> text</hi>
.

NB: One difference to note is that underlined text should be tagged <hi rend="underlined">, rather than “italic”, to indicate what is happening in the manuscript, not what will happen on the printed page of our volume. It will display in italics online and in the printed volumes.

TLS letters, those that have been typed on the all-caps typewriter bought by CD and FD and given to Semper, should be rendered as smallcaps. Any handwritten corrections should be normal roman type. The important thing to remember is that the typed text, and only the typed text, should be entered as lower case letters and enclosed in a <hi rend="smallCaps"> element.

1.1.17 Diagrams and illustrations

We will replace [DIAG HERE] with
<figure>
 <graphic/>
</figure>
. graphic will ultimately have a url attribute pointing to the image file, but don’t worry about this in the normal course of editing a letter. This code will be automatically rendered as “[DIAG HERE]” until the image file is provided and linked to.

1.1.18 Enclosures

If a letter has an enclosure, put the enclosure within <div type="enclosure"> below <div type="text">. It will have a mandatory subtype which can be either letter or other. IT IS ALSO NECESSARY THAT EACH CONTAINS <div type="transcription"> OR THE TEXT OF THE ENCLOSURE WILL NOT COME THROUGH INTO INDESIGN OR XTF. If there is more than one enclosure, simply do a <div type="enclosure"> for each enclsure and give them different xml:ids. It is also important to make sure the enclosure is within <div type="letter">. As a further complication, if there is an enclosure for which we do not have a main letter, you must still have the empty tags for the letter text, including the text element, even if they're left blank. Otherwise the enclosure text will not appear in InDesign or XTF.

<div type="enclosure" subtype="letter"
 xml:id="encl.1">
<!-- contains a transcription of a single enclosure. This div is optional and should only be included when the file letter has an enclosure -->
<!-- @subtype is required to indicate the type of content the enclosure contains: 'letter' or 'other'. In this case, it's listed as being an enclosed letter. If you need to translate enclosures, just create a div/@type="enclosure" for each one to be translated. -->
 <opener>
<!-- contains the information printed at the top of the enclosed letter, such as the salutation, etc. -->
 </opener>
 <div type="transcription">
<!-- the main body of the enclosed letter goes here -->
 </div>
</div>
<div type="enclosure" subtype="other"
 xml:id="encl.2">
<!-- If there are multiple enclosures, just create an additional sibling div/@type="enclosure" for each one. This sample enclosure is for something that isn't a letter -->
 <div type="transcription">
<!-- the main body of the enclosure goes here -->
 </div>
</div>

1.1.19 Dot notes

Instead of dot notes, we are going to use xml comments in the same place we would have put dot notes, with ATTN at the beginning:

<!--ATTN: -->
. Put them at the end of <div type="letter"> before the footnotes:

<!--ATTN: Second proofreading at Bennington. -->
<!--ATTN: &amp;ldquo;Tyndal&amp;rdquo;sic ELS -->
<!--ATTN: First part of letter not in CD’s hand. calendar correction made. ELS -->

1.1.20 Tnotes/MS alteration notes

If there are tnotes to transcribe, make a div with type with a value of “tnotes”at the end of the letter body, above the footnotes. You will also still see tnotes in the old form, as comments between “!!!TNOTES!!!” and “!!!ENDTNOTES!!!”, but these are merely preserved for reference to make sure no tnotes were accidentally missed when they were converted into a separate div. Edit the tnotes div, and leave the old xml comment tnotes. As you can see below they are mostly the same. The only real difference is that instead of putting a dot at the beginning of each line, simply mark each line as a <note xml:id="tnote.n1">. As you can see, each tnote will need its own xml:id. Also as you can see there is no need for the old “!!!TNOTES!!!” and “!!!ENDTNOTES!!!” code.

<div type="tnotes">
 <note xml:id="tnote.n1">1.00 be] <hi rend="italic">interl</hi>
 </note>
 <note xml:id="tnote.n2">
  <hi rend="italic">Enclosure:</hi> . 1.1 In July] <hi rend="italic">after del</hi> ‘<hi rend="italic">Down, | Beckenham, Kent. | Railway Station | Orpington. S.E.R.</hi>’</note>
</div>
Tnote markers are simple comments:

<!-- tnotes -->
. These come through as the little squares that mark tnotes in the galleys. Do not number these tnote markers as this causes problems with the galleys.

1.1.21 Notes

One big difference to the old system is that footnotes, CD notes, and annotations are all more or less the same thing now. Each type of note will have its own div with type with a value of “cdnotes” or “annotation” or “footnotes” as below:

<text>
 <body>
  <div type="letter">
   <div type="text">
    <opener>
     <salute>Sir</salute>
    </opener>
    <div type="transcription">
     <p>I beg leave to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of July 20<hi rend="superscript">th</hi> enclosing my Diploma as Honorary Mem of Imp. Acad of Sciences &amp;c.<ref target="#foot.f1"/> I hope …</p>
    </div>
   </div>
   <div type="cdnotes">
    <note>
     <hi rend="italic">End of letter</hi>: ‘The average heights of the <hi rend="italic">[</hi>parent<hi rend="italic">]</hi> species are of very different values because different numbers were measured— but I have thought it worth while to give a mean not of all the plants which were measured, but a mean of the means, assuming for the moment that all of equal value.’<ref target="#foot.f3"/>
    </note>
    <note>...</note>
   </div>
  </div>
  <div type="footnotes">
   <note xml:id="foot.f1">See letter from the Kaiserliche Akademie der Wissenschaften, 20 July 1875, and Appendix III.</note>
   <note xml:id="foot.f2">CD’s note is a rough draft of text published in …</note>
  </div>
 </body>
</text>

1.1.22 Footnotes

Within <div type="footnotes">, simple create a <note> for each note. Each note should have an xml:id that is pointed to by ref’s target attribute (e.g. ‘foot.f1’ for <ref target="#foot.f1" />):

<note xml:id="foot.f1">The year is established by the relationship between this letter and the letter from John Scott, [1-11] April [1863].</note>

Please make sure that the footnotes div (<div type="footnotes">) is not inside another div. It must be the last element inside the body tag, below the other divs.

When they come through online or in print, the footnotes and footnote markers will automatically be correctly numbered according to where they appear in the final version of the document. The most important thing is that each ref’s target attribute points to the note containing the desired footnote content (e.g <ref target="#foot.f1" /> points to <note xml:id="foot.f1">). While editors should naturally use semantically meaningful values for the note’s xml:id attribute (e.g. foot.f1, foot.f2, foot.f3), the actual textual content of this attribute is irrelevant for the final numbering of the notes. As far as the code responsible for numbering them is concerned, the editor could have given the notes xm:id values of larry, moe and curly. All that actually matters is that each ref’s target attribute points to the right note’s xml:id value.

1.1.23 CD notes and annotations

Treat CD notes and annotations basically the same–the only difference is that CD notes will be in note elements in <div type="cdnotes"> and annotations will be note elements in <div type="annotations">. The divs for each of CD notes and annotations should be within <div type="letter"> but outside <div type="text"> and <div type="transcription">. If you're having trouble seeing the structure of a letter, remember that you can collapse divs by clicking the arrow next to the line number where the div opens (just remember to put it back later so you don’t get confused). Each item will be a note but within that just type out the line numbers and the rest of the text as before:

<note>1.1 pantry] <hi rend="italic">after</hi> ‘warm’<hi rend="italic">interl ink</hi>
</note>

You can put footnote markers in if you need to just as you would in the letter text.

2

2.1

2.1.1 Appendix I: Dates

Dates should be encoded using date and they contain two major parts:

  • 1) the textual content of the element containing a natural language version of the date (e.g. 1 Jan 1880; after 1 Jan 1880; 22 June 1874–82)
  • 2) one (or possibly two) attributes (when, notBefore and notAfter) containing ISO date values (yyyy-mm-dd) entered into one or more of the possible three attributes and which is used for sorting and searching the letters.
1) The textual contents of date should contain a natural language version of the date, entered largely according to existing practices (e.g. 1 Jan 1880; after 1 Jan 1880; before 1 Jan 1880; 1-10 Jan 1880; Oct–Dec 1846, or 22 June 1874–82). If the date (or a portion of it) has been inferred or supplied (i.e. what would normally have been enclosed within square brackets), wrap it with <supplied> (e.g.
22 June <supplied resp="#mjhawkins">1874–82</supplied>
which renders as ‘22 June [1874–82]’. If this inferred/supplied date would normally have had a question mark after it when entered according to the old practices, be sure to add cert (e.g.
<supplied resp="#mjhawkins" cert="medium">
 <hi rend="italic">c.</hi> 31 January 1878
</supplied>
, which renders as ‘[c. 31 January 1878?]’.

2) An ISO version of the date (‘yyyy-mm-dd’) is additionally stored within one (or more) of three possible attributes:

  • when, which is used when the letter is known (or can be inferred) to have been sent on a precise day
  • notBefore, which is used to record the earliest date the letter could have been sent
  • notAfter, which records the latest date the letter could have been written

2.1.1.1

a) When a letter is known (or can be inferred) to have been written on a precise date, this value should be recorded within when. This is the most commonly used dating attribute since the majority of dates of the letters are relatively straightforward. That is, we know (or have inferred) that it was sent on a specific date (e.g. 6 January 1880). In this case, you would enter the ISO value for the date in when (e.g.
<date when="1880-01-06">6 January 1880</date>
).

If a letter was known to have been written on more than one date (e.g. 1 January 1880 and then a later part added on 9 January 1880), you would create two date elements:

<date when="1880-01-06">1 January 1880</date>
<date when="1880-01-09">9 January 1880</date>

NB: Using multiple <date when="yyyy-mm-dd" /> elements with when does not define a range of dates (i.e. 1-9 January 1880). Rather, it defines multiple specific dates that the letter was known to have been written (i.e. 1 & 9 January 1880). To record date ranges, use notBefore and/or notAfter as described below.

2.1.1.2

b) Sometimes we only know that a date was written within a certain period of time (say 2-6 January 1880), or after a certain date (after 2 January 1880) or before a certain date (before 4 January 1880). In these cases you would use a combination of notBefore and/or notAfter.

When a value is entered in notAfter, what you are saying is that the letter could not be written after that date. In other words, it was written on or before the value in notAfter (
<date notAfter="1880-01-05">before 6 January 1880</date>
(i.e. the letter was written on 5 January or earlier).
When a value is entered in notBefore, you are saying that the letter could not have been written earlier than the date in notBefore. That is, the letter was written on or after that date (
<date notBefore="1880-01-06">after 5 January 1880</date>
(i.e. it was written on 6 January 1880 or later).
When notBefore and notAfter are used together, they define a range of dates (inclusive of the values at both extremes) in which the letter could be written:
<date notBefore="1879-12-24"
 notAfter="1880-01-05">24 December 1879 - 5 January 1880</date>
.

NB: It is vital that careful attention is paid when entering values into notBefore and/or notAfter since they will sometimes differ from the natural language date by +/- one day. The key to entering the correct value is to focus on the meaning of the attribute and what you are trying to communicate in the natural language version of the date. Don’t just enter the ISO version of the natural language date since this will sometimes be an incorrect value to use. For example, if the textual content of the date was written after 6 Jan 1880, that means that it could not have been written before 7 Jan 1880 (<date notBefore="1880-01-07"> - NB: that the date value is one day higher than the textual version). If something was written before 6 Jan 1880, that means it could not have been written after 5 Jan 1880 (<date notAfter="1880-01-05"> - NB: that the date value is one day lower than the textual version). The reason for the addition/subtraction of this single day in the attribute value stems from the fact that the words ‘before’ and ‘after’ employ exclusive reckoning. That is, the date mentioned is not a valid date in the range. If something was written after or before 6 January 1880, it could not have been written 6 January 1880 itself. The TEI elements, in contrast, employ inclusive reckoning. That is, if had entered the ISO version of the date from the first example into notBefore (i.e. <date notBefore="1880-01-06">), you would have been saying that the letter was written after 5 Jan 1880 (or, expressed another way, on or after 6 Jan 1880). While the Darwin Correspondence Project often uses exclusively reckoned terms when describing dates (i.e. after and before), dates and ranges are sometimes expressed in an inclusive fashion like TEI’s attributes (i.e. 5 January 1870 or earlier; on or after 5 January 1870 or 5-9 January 1870). In these instances you wouldn’t need to employ a +/- 1 offset when supplying the attribute value. These would simply be encoded respectively as:

  • <date notAfter="1870-01-05">5 January or earlier</date>
  • <date notBefore="1870-01-14">on or after 14 January 1870</date>
  • <date notBefore="1870-01-05"
     notAfter="1870-01-09">    5-9 January 1870</date>

The key therefore when coding dates is to think carefully about when the letter might have been written and then think about how that information can be expressed using the appropriate attributes. Don’t just take the long form date and blindly put it into the attributes.

2.1.1.3

c) There will be instances when there are multiple mutually exclusive choices for the date. For example, if you are unable to decipher the handwriting fully, you might decide that a letter was written on either 16 or 18 January 1880. Alternatively, you might know that the letter was written on a Wednesday in January 1880 but you aren’t certain which one. In these cases, you’d code each possible date using a separate date element using the appropriate dating attributes for each instance of the dates. You’d then additionally use xml:id and exclude to describe their mutually exclusive relationship:

<date when="1880-01-16" xml:id="date1"
 exclude="#date2">16 January 1880</date>
<date when="1880-01-18" xml:id="date2"
 exclude="#date1">18 January 1880</date>

This code reads as follows. It’s either the date identified with an xml:id value of date1 or it’s the one identified as date2. The exclude attribute on each of those dates is crucial since it defines the other date choices that are mutually exclusive. For example, on the <date xml:id="date1">, the other choices it might be are defined in exclude (namely #date2). On <date xml:id="date2"> the other choices defined in it’s exclude is #date1.

The latter example of some Wednesday in January 1880 would be coded as:

<date when="1880-01-07" xml:id="date1"
 exclude="#date2 #date3 #date4">7 January 1880</date>
<date when="1880-01-14" xml:id="date2"
 exclude="#date1 #date3 #date4">14 January 1880</date>
<date when="1880-01-21" xml:id="date3"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date4">21 January 1880</date>
<date when="1880-01-28" xml:id="date4"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3">28 January 1880</date>

The logic of this coding is similar to the simple two-choice version presented above. If it’s date1, then it’s not any of the dates defined in exclude (namely, #date2, #date3 or #date4). If the date it was written is date2, then it’s not any of the dates defined in exclude (namely, #date1, #date3 or #date4). Etc.

If you knew the day and month something was written but were unsure of the year, you’d employ similar code. For example, if you knew something was written on 7 January 187?, you code this as:

<date when="1870-01-07" n="" xml:id="date1"
 exclude="#date2 #date3 #date4 #date5 #date6 #date7 #date8 #date9 #date10">7 January 1870</date>
<date when="1871-01-07" n="" xml:id="date2"
 exclude="#date1 #date3 #date4 #date5 #date6 #date7 #date8 #date9 #date10">7 January 1871</date>
<date when="1872-01-07" n="" xml:id="date3"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date4 #date5 #date6 #date7 #date8 #date9 #date10">7 January 1872</date>
<date when="1873-01-07" n="" xml:id="date4"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3 #date5 #date6 #date7 #date8 #date9 #date10">7 January 1873</date>
<date when="1874-01-07" n="" xml:id="date5"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3 #date4 #date6 #date7 #date8 #date9 #date10">7 January 1874</date>
<date when="1875-01-07" n="" xml:id="date6"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3 #date4 #date5 #date7 #date8 #date9 #date10">7 January 1875</date>
<date when="1876-01-07" n="" xml:id="date7"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3 #date4 #date5 #date6 #date8 #date9 #date10">7 January 1876</date>
<date when="1877-01-07" n="" xml:id="date8"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3 #date4 #date5 #date6 #date7 #date9 #date10">7 January 1877</date>
<date when="1878-01-07" n="" xml:id="date9"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3 #date4 #date5 #date6 #date7 #date8 #date10">7 January 1878</date>
<date when="1879-01-07" n="" xml:id="date10"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3 #date4 #date5 #date6 #date7 #date8 #date9">7 January 1879</date>

The date elements within ‘excluded’ scenarios can contain any valid combination of the dating attributes to describe each of the mutually exclusive dates. For example, if we knew that a letter was written either on 7 Jan 1880 or 14 Jan 1880 or 7-9 Feb 1880 or sometime after March 1880, this would be coded as:

<date when="1880-01-07" xml:id="date1"
 exclude="#date2 #date3 #date4">7 January 1880</date>
<date when="1880-01-14" xml:id="date2"
 exclude="#date1 #date3 #date4">14 January 1880</date>
<date notBefore="1880-01-07"
 notAfter="1880-01-09" xml:id="date3"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date4">7-9 February 1880</date>
<date when="1880-04-01" xml:id="date4"
 exclude="#date1 #date2 #date3">after March 1880</date>

If all options are plausible but one is more probably than the other, you can assign cert values to the dates, giving the more probably one a value of ‘high’ and the others ‘low’. If both options seem equally plausible, no cert values need be applied.

Because of its complexity, exclude coding is very prone to mistakes. With this in mind, a small file (0-dates) has been created that provides code snippets for anywhere from two to twelve mutually exclusive dates. You just need to copy and paste the snippet for the relevant number of choices in to the letter you are editing and then alter the values of the textual content and attributes as necessary. If more than twelve options are needed, please contact Michael Hawkins and he’ll automatically generate the snippet for you.

2.1.2 Appendix II: Tables

Tables are encoded using table, row and cell.

table may take an option rend, which is chiefly used to define the overall width of the table relative to the size of the browser's viewport. Values may be ‘width05’, ‘width10’ ... ‘width95’, ‘width100’ (in increments of 5) or ‘width33’ and ‘width66’.

cell also has an optional rend. It can take a wide variety of values, stipulating alignment of its contents (‘left’, ‘right’ and ‘centre’), the presence of borders(‘borderAll’, ‘borderBottom’, ‘borderLeft’, ‘borderRight’, ‘borderSides’, ‘borderTop’), and the width of the cell (relative to the table’s width) with the values (‘width05’ to ‘width100’ in increments of 5 as well as ‘width33’ and ‘width66’).

The table below would take up 50% of the browser viewport, with the first two columns being 20% the width of the table each, with the final column taking up the remaining 60% of the table’s width.

<table rend="width50">
 <row>
  <cell rend="width20">A: One</cell>
  <cell rend="width20">A: Two</cell>
  <cell rend="width60">A: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>B: One</cell>
  <cell>B: Two</cell>
  <cell>B: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>C: One</cell>
  <cell>C: Two</cell>
  <cell>C: Three</cell>
 </row>
</table>
A: OneA: TwoA: Three
B: OneB: TwoB: Three
C: OneC: TwoC: Three

It’s important to ensure that each row has the same number of ‘cells’. In the above example, you’ll see that each row contains three cell elements. cell can also take optional cols and rows attributes, which allow you to create cells that span more than one column or row. These attributes affect the ‘cell’ counts in affected rows. If you want to use either of these attributes, it’s vital that the table isn’t inside a block element, like p.

When a cell has an cols attribute it stretches horizontally to so that it spans the number of columns stipulated in that attribute. ‘
<cell cols="3">...</cell>
’, for example, spans three columns. It consequently counts as three cells in that row.
rows stretches the cell vertically so that it spans the number of rows specificed in that attribute. ‘
<cell rows="3">...</cell>
’ would stretch vertically to cover three rows, including the one that contains that element. It then creates a ‘phantom cell’ in the same relative position in the following two rows. These ‘phantom cells’ count as a cell when determining the number of cells within that row.
<table>
 <row>
<!-- This row has three cells -->
  <cell>A: One</cell>
  <cell rend="width10" rows="3">This is narrow column spans three rows</cell>
  <cell>A: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>B: One</cell>
<!-- The cell with @rows above creates a phantom cell here. The total 'cell' count in this row, therefore, is 3.-->
  <cell>B: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>C: One</cell>
<!-- The cell with @rows above creates a phantom cell here. The total 'cell' count in this row, therefore, is 3.-->
  <cell>C: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>D: One</cell>
  <cell>D: Two</cell>
  <cell>D: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
<!-- This row has three 'cells' because of the @cols attr below -->
  <cell cols="3">This is one long cell that spans all three cells</cell>
 </row>
</table>

It would render as:

A: OneThis is narrow column spans three rowsA: Three
B: OneB: Three
C: OneC: Three
D: OneD: TwoD: Three
This is one long cell that spans all three cells. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

rows is largely going to be used in tables that have large braces that stretch to span more than one row, as below:

A: One}Single item
B: One
C: One
⏟
This is one long cell

It’s coded as:

<table rend="width20">
 <row>
  <cell>A: One</cell>
  <cell rows="3">
   <hi rend="stretchyVertical">}</hi>
  </cell>
  <cell rows="3">Single item</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>B: One</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>C: One</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell cols="3">
   <hi rend="stretchyHorizontal">&#x23DF;</hi>
  </cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell cols="3">This is one long cell</cell>
 </row>
</table>

To create a vertical stretchy bracket, the cell must:

  • span more than one row with an rows attribute
  • contain a single hi with a rend equal to ‘stretchyVertical’
  • the hi must contain a single character taken from the list of stretchy braces below.

To create a horizontal stretchy bracket:

  • the table must have a specified width, even if it's just ‘width100’ to indicate that it fills the entire viewport.
  • the cell must span more than one column with an cols attribute
  • the spanning cell must contain a single hi with a rend equal to ‘stretchyHorizontal’
  • the hi must contain a single character taken from the list of stretchy braces below.
Brace typeLeft facingRight facingUpward facingDownward facing
Curly{}⏞ or &#x23DE;⏟ or &#x23DF;
Rounded()⏜ or &#x23DC;⏝ or &#x23DD;
Square[]⎴ or &#x23B4;⎵ or &#x23B5;

You can specify the vertical alignment of a cell that spans multiple rows using vAlignTop (aligns a cell to the baseline of the top line), vAlignMiddle (the default setting, which centres the text vertically in the middle of the cell) and vAlignBottom (aligns a cell to the baseline of the bottom line)

A: One}Default
A: Two
A: Three
A: Three
A: Four
B: One}Top
B: Two
B: Three
B: Four
C: Three}Bottom
C: Two
C: Three
C: Four
D: One}Middle
D: Two
D: Three
D: Four

And here's the code that produces this table:

<table rend="width20">
 <row>
  <cell>A: One</cell>
  <cell rows="3">
   <hi rend="stretchyVertical">}</hi>
  </cell>
  <cell rows="3">Default</cell>
<!-- No rend, so default vertical centering -->
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>A: Two</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>A: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>A: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>A: Four</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>B: One</cell>
  <cell rows="3">
   <hi rend="stretchyVertical">}</hi>
  </cell>
  <cell rows="3" rend="vAlignTop">Top</cell>
<!-- rend to align to the top -->
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>B: Two</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>B: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>B: Four</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>C: Three</cell>
  <cell rows="3">
   <hi rend="stretchyVertical">}</hi>
  </cell>
  <cell rows="3" rend="vAlignBottom">Bottom</cell>
<!-- rend to align to the bottom -->
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>C: Two</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>C: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>C: Four</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>D: One</cell>
  <cell rows="3">
   <hi rend="stretchyVertical">}</hi>
  </cell>
  <cell rows="3" rend="vAlignMiddle">Middle</cell>
<!-- manually specifying vertical centering -->
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>D: Two</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>D: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>D: Four</cell>
 </row>
</table>

Tables, rows and cells can also have borders on any of their sides using rend and the values ‘borderAll’ (border on all sides), ‘borderBottom’ (border on bottom), ‘borderLeft’ border on left), ‘borderRight’ (border on right), ‘borderSides’ (border on both left and right), and ‘borderTop’ (border on top). You can apply multiple values within the same rend. For example, a cell coded as <cell rend="borderTop borderLeft">> would have textual content on both the top and left.

<table rend="width50 borderTop borderBottom">
 <row>
  <cell rend="width20">A: One</cell>
  <cell rend="width20">A: Two</cell>
  <cell rend="width60 borderLeft">A: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>B: One</cell>
  <cell>B: Two</cell>
  <cell rend="borderBottom borderLeft">B: Three</cell>
 </row>
 <row>
  <cell>Total</cell>
  <cell/>
  <cell>C: Four</cell>
 </row>
</table>

Would render as:

A: OneA: TwoA: Three
B: OneB: TwoB: Three
TotalC: Four

NB: adjacent borders within a table will collapse into a single border. If you had two cells (the first with a right border and the second with a left border), you would not have two borders separating them. You would have one. If you need double borders, contact Mike and he will implement a proper solution with new rend values.

<table rend="width50 borderTop borderBottom">
 <row>
  <cell rend="width20">A: One</cell>
<!-- Notice that the borderRight and borderLeft on these two cells collapse into a single border -->
  <cell rend="width20 borderRight">A: Two</cell>
  <cell rend="width60 borderLeft">A: Three</cell>
 </row>
</table>

And here are the borders collapsed (i.e. a single border line, not two as you would expect with the coding):

A: OneA: TwoA: Three

<bibl>

<bibl> (bibliographic citation) contains a loosely-structured bibliographic citation of which the sub-components may or may not be explicitly tagged. It is currently used used in two places within the Darwin Correspondence files: 1) as a generic container for the old DarML provenance element; 2) as a container for bibliographical references for related items (see relatedItem). [3.12.1. Methods of Encoding Bibliographic References and Lists of References 2.2.7. The Source Description 15.3.2. Declarable Elements]
Modulecore — Appendix III: Element Set
Attributes
cert(certainty) signifies the degree of certainty associated with the intervention or interpretation.
Derived fromatt.global.responsibility
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.probCert
Note

This element should not be used by editors. It is only used to indicate the accuracy of the machine-processing by the agent recorded in resp.

NB: Any editor changing or reviewing this element should confirm its accuracy and make any changes necessary. resp and cert can be removed once the data has been reviewed or fixed by the editor.

resp(responsible party) indicates the agency responsible for the intervention or interpretation, for example an editor or transcriber.
Derived fromatt.global.responsibility

This element should not be used by editors. It is only used to indicate the agent that performed the global update of this field. It will almost always be ‘#mjhawkins’ or ‘#automat’.

Note

<bibl type="provenance"> is a natural language description of the source(s) of the text as it appeared in both the print and online edition. bibl contained in <relatedItem type="CUL"> contains the classmark of a different version of the letter than the text published in the edition, usually a copy. bibl contained in <relatedItem type="publication"> indicates that the source of the text is a publication rather than a manuscript. key should only be used on <bibl type="printedSource">

bibl also appears inside relatedItem. relatedItems represent other potential sources of the text of the letter or other places it has been published; this can be a handwritten draft or copy, a reproduction of the letter in a newspaper, magazine, or life and letters volume, or it could be another volume within the Correspondence. This is differentiated by type which can take the values copy, draft, or publication, with an optional subtype to indicate whether the item is in the UL.

Example
<bibl type="provenance">Archives of the Gray Herbarium, Harvard University (121)</bibl>
Example
<relatedItem type="copy" subtyp="CUL">
 <bibl>DAR 153: 254</bibl>
</relatedItem>
Example
<relatedItem type="publication">
 <bibl>HRS, no. 112</bibl>
</relatedItem>
Schematron

<sch:rule context="tei:bibl[@type='provenance']">
<sch:report test="count(//tei:bibl[@type='provenance']) gt 1">ERROR: There must only be one <sch:name/>/@type='provenance' in a letter</sch:report>
</sch:rule>

 <alternate minOccurs="0"
  maxOccurs="unbounded">

  <classRef key="model.highlighted"/>
  <classRef key="model.pPart.data"/>
  <classRef key="model.pPart.edit"/>
  <classRef key="model.segLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.ptrLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.biblPart"/>
  <classRef key="model.global"/>
 </alternate>
</content>

Note

When a single page is being cited, use the from and to attributes with an identical value. When no clear endpoint is provided, the from attribute may be used without to; for example a citation such as ‘p. 3ff’ might be encoded <biblScope from="3">p. 3ff</biblScope>.

It is now considered good practice to supply this element as a sibling (rather than a child) of <imprint>, since it supplies information which does not constitute part of the imprint.

<change>

<change> (change) documents a change or set of changes made during the production of a source document, or during the revision of an electronic file. [2.6. The Revision Description 2.4.1. Creation 11.7. Identifying Changes and Revisions]
Moduleheader — Appendix III: Element Set
Attributes
whendate for the change, in iso format.
Derived fromatt.datable.w3c
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.temporal.w3c
statusdescribes the status of a document either currently or, when associated with a dated element, at the time indicated.
Derived fromatt.docStatus
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
alteredPostPublication
cancelled
draft
[Default]

footnoted

sup-finalProofreadCompleted

typedocuments significant stages in the creation, transcription, checking, processing and clearance for release of an electronic file.
Derived fromatt.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
footnotes
letter
translation
Contained by
header: revisionDesc
May contain
core: bibl choice date graphic hi l lb lg list name note p quote ref term title
figures: figure formula table
header: idno
linking: ab anchor seg
msdescription: msDesc
namesdates: orgName persName placeName roleName
character data
Note

Create a new change element with required when attribute giving the date, and content giving a natural-language account of each significant revision. The person who made it goes in a name element with an xml:id value that will be assigned by the senior editors when someone starts work, but is normally based on that person's first initial plus her or his surname, e.g. mhawkins, elsmith or sevans.

Proofreading a file counts as a change even if the proofreader has not in fact made any changes to it since it records that the files has undergone a particular part of our editorial process.

If the xml:id value of any of the people working on the document has previously been declared, subsequent occurrences of their name take a sameAs value of # followed by the relevant string.

Example
<change when="2015-10-02">Converted to TEI P5 by <name xml:id="mjhawkins">Michael Hawkins</name>
</change>
<change when="2015-10-02"
 status="initialProofCompleted">Footnotes cleared for online release by <name sameAs="#apearne">Alison Pearn</name>
</change>
<change when="2016-06-21">Complex table encoded by <name sameAs="#mjhawkins">Michael Hawkins</name>
</change>

<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.specialPara"/>
</content>

Note

This is legacy markup used only for the print volumes, where the title line is pulled for two separate sections of the volume where a letter requires a translation; the first seg points to a footnote that occurs under the letter in the main section of the text while the second points to the footnote that appears in the translations appendix of that volume.

Example
<title xml:id="main_title">From William Marshall<choice>
  <seg type="original">
   <ref target="#foot.f1"/>
  </seg>
  <seg type="translation">
   <seg target="#foot_trans.f1"/>
  </seg>
 </choice>   2 June 1875</title>

The persNames of sender and recipient should always have a ref connecting to a name register file. There should always be a date of sending, as accurate as can be determined. There will only sometimes be a placeName and there will rarely be a date of receipt.

 </date>

 <persName key="../nameregs/nameregs_2357.xml">Hooker, J. D.</persName>
</correspAction>
